context: Hi there! Can you tell me some food good for acid reflux?
Hi, do you mean acid reflux of the stomach?
Yes.

Sure, here is a list of foods suitable for acid reflux and indigestion: non-citrus fruits (like watermelons, bananas, berries, apples, and pears), fresh vegetables (like cabbage and beets), lean meats (chicken and turkey), and oily fish (such as salmon and tuna). In addition, gingerroot tea, almond, chamomile tea, baking soda, and cider vinegar. Chewing gum helps increase saliva production and reduces acid in the esophagus. But avoid peppermint or spearmint gum. Drinking water can also help by diluting stomach acid and relieving symptoms.

context: Hi there! Can you tell me some food good for acid reflux?
Hi, do you mean acid reflux of the stomach?
Yes.

Sure, here is a list of foods suitable for acid reflux and indigestion: non-citrus fruits (like watermelons, bananas, berries, apples, and pears), fresh vegetables (like cabbage and beets), lean meats (chicken and turkey), and oily fish (such as salmon and tuna). In addition, gingerroot tea, almond, chamomile tea, baking soda, and cider vinegar. Chewing gum helps increase saliva production and reduces acid in the esophagus. But avoid peppermint or spearmint gum. Drinking water can also help by diluting stomach acid and relieving symptoms.
How about the fruits I mentioned before?

When the stomach acid travels up, it leads to acid reflux or heartburn. While many fruits make acid reflux worse (due to their acidity levels), mangoes are very close to neutral on "The pH Scale," so they will likely not worsen acid reflux. If you do experience heartburn or acid reflux from mangoes, it is probably best to avoid the fruit altogether. The acid in citrus fruits like kiwis triggers reflux symptoms by relaxing the lower esophageal sphincter. Watermelon is considered good for acid reflux while pomegranate is not good because it is as acidic as citrus fruits. Do you want me to also list other food you should avoid?

Why does it happen? Does it have a reason?

Acid reflux is a condition that occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)--a muscle between the stomach and esophagus-- malfunctions, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus. This can cause a burning sensation in your heart and chest, which we often refer to as "heartburn." Over time, prolonged acid reflux can cause damage to the esophagus and potentially lead to the chronic form of the condition called GERD. Acid reflux happens due to improper functioning of the LES. Acid reflux normally happens when we eat certain foods that stimulate excess acid production; however, for some people, genetics plays a role in reflux. Eating large meals, lying down straight after eating, or snacking close to bedtime are also common triggers of reflux. Being overweight means that you are more likely to suffer from reflux because of increased pressure on your stomach, which can force open the valve after a meal. Some people find that acid reflux is worse when they are stressed. Acid reflux also happens due to a weakness of the sphincter muscle, or when the stomach produces too much acid and not enough protective mucus. There is also something called a hiatus hernia; due to a gap in the diaphragm, parts of the stomach can move into the chest, which increases the risk of reflux.

Acid reflux is a condition that occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)--a muscle between the stomach and esophagus-- malfunctions, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus. This can cause a burning sensation in your heart and chest, which we often refer to as "heartburn." Over time, prolonged acid reflux can cause damage to the esophagus and potentially lead to the chronic form of the condition called GERD. Acid reflux happens due to improper functioning of the LES. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and H2 blockers both reduce stomach acid, but they work in different ways. Because PPIs act at the final stage and bind irreversibly, they are generally more effective than H2 blockers in reducing stomach acid.

context: I'm thinking of having a healthier and more active lifestyle. Where can I get started?

A healthy lifestyle includes physical, mental, and spiritual health. Be mindful of your daily habits and make changes if needed to align with your goals. To be active, think proactive. Consider the ways that you can be more active in the tasks you already do. Here are a few tips to becoming more active: Schedule active time with friends and family. Instead of going out for dinner or seeing a movie, go ahead and plan to spend a day at the park or go for a hike at a local park. Start playing sports again. Join a local sport league for adults or take part in a walking or running club in your neighbourhood. Rotate your commute. Take every chance you can to walk or bike instead of drive, whether it is to work, to the store or to a friend's house. Move around at work. Instead of sitting in your desk chair the whole day through, stand up or sit on an exercise ball.

There are four different types of coffee beans in the world. 1) Arabica makes up most coffee grown at present, accounting for about 60% of commercial coffee production. It originated in Ethiopia, where it grows wild. However, people first cultivated it in Yemen, and it is from there that it takes its name. Arabica beans have sweeter and more complex flavors than Robusta coffee beans, which is why they currently dominate coffee markets, especially specialty coffee markets. Arabica coffee beans have a bright acidity, medium body, and multiple layers of flavor. They are well suited to be brewed pour-over style, which lets their subtleties shine more than espresso or immersion brewing. 2) Robusta is the second most commonly grown type of coffee bean. Robusta's name comes from being more robust than the Arabica plants, which is why you can grow it in a broader range of environments. Therefore, it is less prone to disease. However, despite these advantages, it remains less popular than Arabica because its flavors and aromas aren't as desirable. Robusta beans are known for having a darker, earthier flavor, and for this reason, they are most often subjected to a darker roast to better match their natural character. The degradation of simple sugars and polysaccharides during roasting creates sweet and caramelized aromas. As they spend more time roasting, they become much darker and release some extra oil as well. This also really impacts the flavor of the coffee. It's also important to note that a large amount of coffee's natural caffeine content is lost as roasting continues. The longer you cook or roast something, the fewer nutrients remain. As you roast coffee for longer, the chlorogenic acid begins to seep out. Chlorogenic acid is considered an antioxidant, which means it repairs your body and protects you from diseases like cancer. There are four common roast levels: Light roasts (also called cinnamon roasts) retain the most caffeine and acidity. You'll taste more of the floral or fruity notes of the bean and get a thinner body. Medium roasts: This is the most balanced of the roasts. You'll get some acidity with more sweetness and aroma. They're the most common roast in the United States, which has led to the nickname American roast. Medium-dark roasts: Also called city roasts, these have the bittersweet aftertaste most people associate with coffee. They have a high aroma and sweetness with almost no acidity, and may have some visible oil on the surface of the beans. Dark roasts: You may also hear this called a French roast or Italian roast. These beans are nearly black and very oily, and you'll taste more of the roast than the bean in the cup. Dark roasts have the least caffeine and acid and tend to be very bitter, with a full body and lingering aftertaste. The Medium-dark roasts can be a good option for you as they have no acidity.

Sourness in homemade wine is typically caused by too much fruit acid. This can happen when overly acidic fruits are used or when too much fruit is included in the recipe. That's totally fair, it can be hard to tell, so let's break down the anatomy of the finger. Three bones and three hinged joints make up the finger. Ligaments connect and stabilize the bones, while tendons connect muscle to bone, transferring to the bone any forces created by the muscles. Flexor tendons in the fingers attach to muscles in the forearms that pull on the tendons, bend the fingers, and allow us to crimp. Connective tissue encases the tendons, forming a sheath with five thickened areas that create the annular pulleys (A1, A2, A3, A4, and A5), which keep the tendon close to the bone when bending the fingers.

If you have pain in your A2 pulley as a climber, here is what to do next, depending on the severity of the injury: Grade 1: Pulley sprain. A partial tear of a single pulley. Solution: No need for immobilization. Begin gentle range-of-motion exercises, bend the finger until it feels tight, hold for 2-3 seconds, relax, and repeat 10 times for several sessions each day. Now perform the same exercise, only straighten the finger. Avoid pushing through pain. Grade 2: Complete A4 or partial A2, A3 tear/rupture. Either the A4 pulley is completely torn, or A2 and A3 are both partially torn. Solution: One to two weeks of immobilization with a finger-immobilization splint or a pulley-protection splint. Gentle range-of-motion exercises. If it persists, you can seek a diagnosis from a climbing-knowledgeable physician or orthopaedic surgeon, who can assess the damage with an ultrasound or MRI. This will help determine the level of care needed, as well as confirm and check possible damage to the rest of your hand.

I don't like taking supplements. How to tape?

Yes, it is totally understandable, many people prefer not to take supplements. When it comes to taping, it can be a helpful way to protect an injured pulley. Since taping restricts finger movement, it prevents you from using the injured area in ways that could make the damage worse, making it a generally safe and recommended approach. According to Dave Saunders, a physiotherapist and climbing injury specialist known for his work on hand and finger injuries in climbers, effective taping for A2 and A3 pulley injuries should limit the finger's ability to bend at the middle joint. To apply the tape correctly, note the three creases on the front of your finger, starting from the base. With your finger straight, begin taping from halfway between the first and second crease and finish halfway between the second and third, overlapping the tape by 50%. Once taped, you'll notice you can't crimp anymore, which is actually a good thing for healing. The goal is to restrict the range of motion at the injured joint so that crimping becomes impossible, protecting the pulley during recovery.

For A2 pulley injuries, the most common pulley injury for climbers, the pain usually arises at the base of the finger and is noticeable when trying to straighten or bend the finger. For A2-A4 ruptures, there may be bowstringing, bulging at the base of the finger, which can be detected by resisting finger bending at the fingertip. Those are usually associated with pain on the front of the finger. Otherwise, if you see difficulties with bending your finger, this can be due to damage on the tendon, it can be the case if you also have an open injury or a cut on the open side of your hand. Finally, if you feel that the pain is more on the side of the finger, then this might be the collateral ligaments of the fingers.
I have pain in the front of the finger, especially when crimping, but I cannot see any bowstring, can this still be the A2 pulley?

When you bend your finger, normally the tendon stays snug against the bone because the pulleys hold it down. In very serious cases, if you have a complete rupture of the pulley (especially A2), the tendon lifts off the bone, forming a visible or palpable "bowstring" under the skin. However, you can also have just a strain on the A2 pulley, with pain when crimping, which is less serious than the complete rupture, but still needs some rest. It is a good sign if you don't have a visible bowstring.
I understand, what are the next steps?

If you have pain in your A2 pulley as a climber, here is what to do next, depending on the severity of the injury: Grade 1: Pulley sprain. A partial tear of a single pulley. Solution: No need for immobilization. Begin gentle range-of-motion exercises, bend the finger until it feels tight, hold for 2-3 seconds, relax, and repeat 10 times for several sessions each day. Now perform the same exercise, only straighten the finger. Avoid pushing through pain. Grade 2: Complete A4 or partial A2, A3 tear/rupture. Either the A4 pulley is completely torn, or A2 and A3 are both partially torn. Solution: One to two weeks of immobilization with a finger-immobilization splint or a pulley-protection splint. Gentle range-of-motion exercises. If it persists, you can seek a diagnosis from a climbing-knowledgeable physician or orthopaedic surgeon, who can assess the damage with an ultrasound or MRI. This will help determine the level of care needed, as well as confirm and check possible damage to the rest of your hand.
I don't think I want to do an MRI. Anyway, what are the risks if I don't rest?

You risk damaging the pulley even more, which can be very dangerous and lead to surgery. From past patients that went through the surgery, most of them complained of reduced finger dexterity while performing their daily activities and work, and not being able to perform as they use to at climbing. This is not advisable. Even without going as far as the surgery, it can lead to a worsening of the tear, a bowstring, over-compensation from another part of your hand and risk of further injuries. Your body might also do inadequate healing with excessive scar tissue and limit your flexibility in the future.
I will take it slow and take a few weeks off. What are some advice for when I start again?

That's a good spirit. It is advised to spend the first weeks climbing relatively easy routes with big holds, good footholds and keeping sessions short. Stay away from overhangs and campus boards. You can return to full-force climbing if easy climbing yields no pain. Continue taping (it will also serve as a mental note of the previous injury) and avoid tweaky crimps and pockets for several months. Collagen supplements may also help the pulley recover faster by providing much needed building block nutrients. It is also good to re-start in indoor climbing rather than outdoor directly, as low temperatures increase the risk of injury.
I don't like taking supplements. How to tape?

Yes, it is totally understandable, many people prefer not to take supplements. When it comes to taping, it can be a helpful way to protect an injured pulley. Since taping restricts finger movement, it prevents you from using the injured area in ways that could make the damage worse, making it a generally safe and recommended approach. According to Dave Saunders, a physiotherapist and climbing injury specialist known for his work on hand and finger injuries in climbers, effective taping for A2 and A3 pulley injuries should limit the finger's ability to bend at the middle joint. To apply the tape correctly, note the three creases on the front of your finger, starting from the base. With your finger straight, begin taping from halfway between the first and second crease and finish halfway between the second and third, overlapping the tape by 50%. Once taped, you'll notice you can't crimp anymore, which is actually a good thing for healing. The goal is to restrict the range of motion at the injured joint so that crimping becomes impossible, protecting the pulley during recovery.
What about the H shape?

H-taping is generally more effective than standard circumferential taping for supporting injured finger pulleys, especially the A2 and A3. To apply an H-tape correctly, start with a piece of athletic tape about 4 inches long and the full width of the roll. From each end, tear lengthwise inward, stopping about half an inch before reaching the centre, so you are left with a narrow "bridge" between two tails. This creates the "H" shape. Place the central bridge of the tape over the palmar side (the inner surface) of the middle joint of the injured finger. Start by wrapping the two tails around the section of the finger closer to the palm (proximal phalanx), anchoring it firmly. Then, slightly bend the finger, about 30 degrees at the joint, and wrap the other two tails around the section of the finger beyond the joint (middle phalanx). This technique limits extension and flexion at the joint, providing mechanical support to reduce stress on the injured pulley while still allowing controlled movement for rehab.

After a couple of weeks, gentle swimming can actually support circulation and mobility without putting too much strain on the finger. Just make sure to protect your hand; using gloves can help keep it warm and prevent further stress. As always, listen to your body and avoid any strokes or movements that cause discomfort.
I think I will combine yoga with swimming; do you know of any water spot nearby?

Yoga and swimming make a great combination for both fitness and recovery. If you're near London, there are several good options for outdoor swimming. In the north, you can check out the West Reservoir Centre in Hackney. If you're based in the south, Beckenham Place Park in Lewisham features a Georgian lake that's been transformed into a popular swimming spot in recent years.
What budget should I consider for this activity?

Swimming can be a very cheap sport. Now, for wild swim in cold water, better protect yourself against the cold. It would be around 160 pounds if you take a full swimming kit. This would include gloves, swimming suit, goggles, and the hair protection. You can also consider buying a smartwatch to record your session, would this interest you?
And for yoga?

For yoga, the initial costs are generally low since you don't need much equipment, just comfortable clothing and, optionally, a yoga mat (most studios provide them). The main expense comes from how you choose to participate: drop-in classes typically cost EUR15-25 each; monthly memberships range from $55 to $150 USD for standard studios, and up to $500 USD for premium unlimited access. If you're interested in a deeper experience, yoga retreats or seminars, including accommodation and meals, usually cost between EUR800 and EUR1,200 for 5 to 7 nights. Overall, you can budget around EUR80-EUR150 per month for regular practice. Would you like more details for one of the options?
I would rather do it at home, any other solution?

Yes sure, you can use an app on your phone, with descriptions of poses, and hundreds of videos to help you with yoga and meditation, for example, Yoga.com or daily Yoga. Also, you can consider a private teacher that you can call from your home directly for live sessions. Does this work better for you?

Great! Here's a checklist to get you started on your 10-mile training journey: 1. Plan Ahead: Training for a 10-mile run takes time, ideally several months. Start preparing early to build your endurance gradually and safely. 2. Run Slow to Get Strong: Focus on building endurance by running at a comfortable pace. Your long-run pace should be about 1 to 2 minutes per mile slower than your short-run or race pace. Plan a long run every other weekend, increasing the distance by about half a mile each time. The key is consistency and patience. 3. Set Your Own Goals: If you're aged 17 to 21 and in good health, running a 6:30 mile puts you in the top 1% for that age group, according to the U.S. Army standards. That translates to a 1:05:00 finish for 10 miles. But remember that your journey is yours alone. 4. Practice Mid-Run Fuelling: For any run longer than 60 minutes, your body will need fuel. Whether it's energy gels, dates, or other snacks, experiment during training to find what works best for you. Never try something new on race day. 5. Stay Hydrated: A portable water bottle or hydration belt is a must for long runs. Try different setups and go with what feels most comfortable for you. Let me know if you want further help on how to organize your training, for example, how many days per week do you want to train? What time of day works best for you to run? What is your current fitness level?

How can I figure out my threshold?

While exercising above the threshold, more lactate is produced than can be removed from the muscle. A reliable test method for the threshold is the talk test. If you are exercising and can explain easily to someone what you (for example) did on the weekend, you are below the threshold. If you have difficulty explaining, you are at the threshold. And if you can't, then you are above the threshold.

Running shoes are important because they directly affect your comfort, performance, and risk of injury. If your shoes are not comfortable, it can change the way you run and lead to problems like blisters, joint pain, or muscle strain. Running shoes are specially designed for forward motion and repetitive impact, unlike walking or gym shoes, which may not give the right support. It's also important to choose shoes that match both the size and shape of your foot. Many brands offer different widths to make sure the shoe fits properly. Shoes that are too tight or too loose can cause discomfort or injuries over time. Always use shoes designed for running. Great! Here's a checklist to get you started on your 10-mile training journey: 1. Plan Ahead: Training for a 10-mile run takes time, ideally several months. Start preparing early to build your endurance gradually and safely. 2. Run Slow to Get Strong: Focus on building endurance by running at a comfortable pace. Your long-run pace should be about 1 to 2 minutes per mile slower than your short-run or race pace. Plan a long run every other weekend, increasing the distance by about half a mile each time. The key is consistency and patience. 3. Set Your Own Goals: If you're aged 17 to 21 and in good health, running a 6:30 mile puts you in the top 1% for that age group, according to the U.S. Army standards. That translates to a 1:05:00 finish for 10 miles. But remember that your journey is yours alone. 4. Practice Mid-Run Fuelling: For any run longer than 60 minutes, your body will need fuel. Whether it's energy gels, dates, or other snacks, experiment during training to find what works best for you. Never try something new on race day. 5. Stay Hydrated: A portable water bottle or hydration belt is a must for long runs. Try different setups and go with what feels most comfortable for you. Let me know if you want further help on how to organize your training, for example, how many days per week do you want to train? What time of day works best for you to run? What is your current fitness level?

How can I figure out my threshold?

While exercising above the threshold, more lactate is produced than can be removed from the muscle. A reliable test method for the threshold is the talk test. For a multi-sport shoe that works well for both running and everyday life, the Hoka One One Hupana Wool is a solid choice. It's lightweight, around 9 ounces, with a smooth and responsive ride thanks to its RMAT midsole and outsole--a blend of rubber and EVA foam that offers both durability and cushioning. The design is more subdued than typical Hokas, making it versatile for casual wear. It's comfortable enough for all-day use while still providing the performance needed for runs or light workouts. Another good option is the Saucony Liteform Miles, which is especially travel-friendly. It features a highly flexible outsole made from Triflex rubber for excellent traction, breathable materials, and memory foam insoles for added comfort. It fits snugly without being tight, making it great for walking, running, and general gym use. Both of these shoes offer the versatility you're looking for--blending athletic function with everyday comfort and style.

context: Hi, can you help me prepare for my trip to New York?
Yes, sure. Do you want some general tips about traveling, or do you look for something specific?
Traveling and visit.

If you have time, consider exploring all five boroughs of New York City, each with its own unique vibe. Manhattan is the city's iconic core, with landmarks like Central Park, Times Square, the Empire State Building, and the world-class Metropolitan Museum of Art, which features everything from ancient Egyptian funeral art to contemporary American painting. Cross the Brooklyn Bridge into Brooklyn, known for its creative energy, historic brownstones, and vibrant neighborhoods like Williamsburg. Queens is the city's most diverse borough, offering incredible international food and landmarks like Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. The Bronx, birthplace of hip-hop, is home to Yankee Stadium, the Bronx Zoo, and a strong cultural identity. Staten Island offers a quieter, greener escape with parks, beaches, and stunning views from the free ferry ride past the Statue of Liberty. Together, the five boroughs form a city of endless variety and character.

Yes, there is a museum about New York's subways, called the New York Transit Museum. Museums Special interest Boerum Hill New York Transit Museum recounts subway history with a vintage fleet of restored cars that let visitors climb aboard to imagine themselves as straphangers from different decades dating back to the subway opening in 1904. However, the world's first subway was London's Metropolitan Railway that opened in 1863 with steam powered trains.

How's your preparation for the race going? Once it's all done, it definitely makes sense to take some time to relax, here are some options: 1. Central Park is the most popular park in New York, but there are plenty of hidden spots that aren't as swarmed with tourism. One of these in-the-know hangouts is Sheep Meadow, a 15-acre preserve in the western part of the Park between 66th to 69th Streets. 2. Tudor City Overpass (42nd St - map it): Go as far east as you can on 42nd Street in Manhattan, and you'll land on a quiet, scenic refuge just steps from the busiest part of town. Tudor City Overpass is great for snapping that perfectly symmetrical landscape photo overlooking the city (especially during Manhattanhenge), and there are two landmark parks and staircases flanking each side. You'll almost forget you're in Midtown. 3. AIRE Ancient Baths. AIRE has just eight luxurious spas worldwide, with one being in New York's Tribeca. Relaxing treatments to choose from include soaking in thermal baths, getting a massage, and enjoying a Himalayan salt scrub. There's even a wine and bath experience - the perfect way to unwind after a long week.

Making your own cake from scratch with wholesome ingredients like whole grain flour, oats, fruit, nuts, or dark chocolate is a great way to make it healthier. Swapping out processed ingredients, cutting back on sugar and fat, and skipping artificial colors or sugary toppings can make a big difference. Canola oil is a lighter alternative to butter, with less saturated fat and more heart-friendly monounsaturated fats. For sweeteners, stevia is a top choice, followed by xylitol, erythritol, and yacon syrup. Natural options like honey, molasses or maple syrup are better than white sugar but should still be used in moderation. Yogurt is another great substitute, using one cup of fat-free yogurt instead of oil can lighten the recipe, just be sure to adjust other liquids to avoid an overly wet batter. Fruit juice adds some nutrients like vitamin C, but it's still high in sugar and lacks the fiber of whole fruits, so it's best used in small amounts.

context: Hey there! I am so excited! I got pregnant!
Congratulations! I am sure you have many questions now. What do you want to know?
I heard so much controversy about breastfeeding. Is it really bad to do it?

No, breastfeeding is not bad -- in fact, it's strongly recommended by health experts for both infants and mothers due to its many health benefits. According to the NHMRC, exclusive breastfeeding for around the first six months and continuing up to 12 months or longer provides clear benefits for both infants and mothers. These benefits include optimal nutrition and improved health outcomes in both the short and long term. Similarly, the UK GP Infant Feeding Network notes that breastfeeding plays a crucial role in infant wellbeing, maternal health, and secure infant attachment. They, along with the World Health Organization, recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months, followed by continued breastfeeding alongside solid foods up to 2 years of age or beyond. So, while there may be public controversy or social challenges around breastfeeding, from a medical and health perspective, it is highly beneficial and not harmful.

You don't need a special diet while you're breastfeeding - just try to include a well-balanced, healthy variety of the following: Fruit and vegetables, starchy foods (carbohydrates), protein, dairy. You said you are interested in low-carb diets, but a low-carb diet can be dangerous to breastfeeding moms and has been reported to be life-threatening. While breastfeeding you need to drink more than you normally would. It is recommended that nursing moms drink about 12 glasses of water per day to stay well hydrated. The good news is that does not all have to be water. There are many great lactation drinks that can help to stay hydrated and produce more breast milk at the same time. For example, coconut water drinks for breastfeeding, lactation latte, or the breastfeeding protein shake. Importantly, contrary to some beliefs, studies have shown that alcohol interferes with the release of oxytocin which affects the let-down of breast milk, which means that rather than increasing milk supply, breast milk volumes are more likely to be lowered by alcohol.

Some women get sore, cracked or painful nipples in the early days of breastfeeding. This usually happens if your baby isn't positioned or attached well at the breast. If a baby only sucks the nipple rather than taking a good mouthful of breast, then their tongue or roof of the mouth may rub on the nipple. Your midwife, health visitor or breastfeeding counsellor might be able to help identify any other underlying issues. Some women find rubbing breast milk onto their nipples can be soothing. Products like Vaseline or lanolin can help with dry or cracked nipples (although there's little evidence to show what really works well). After each feed, let your nipples dry before getting dressed - change your breast pads after every feed. Avoid using soap, as this can dry out your skin. If possible, only wear cotton, non-underwired bras. It's best to avoid using nipple shields and breast shells - these will not improve your baby's attachment to the breast. Try not to shorten feeds - doing so will not ease the pain and may reduce your milk supply. Moreover, you do not need to have your baby drink your milk directly. "Expressing" means taking milk from your breast without your baby suckling. You can use a pump or you can do it by hand.

Microneedling stimulates the production of collagen and elastin. The collagen hydrates the skin cells, making them plump and full. This naturally shrinks the size of the pores, making your skin look flawless and beautiful. Additionally, microneedling addresses dark spots by breaking up melanin clusters and stimulating skin cell regeneration to produce healthy, unpigmented new tissue. CO2 laser treatment is recommended for anyone who is looking to do the following: Minimize the visibility of wrinkles and fine lines on the face. Reduce the appearance of sun-damaged spots, minimize the size of pores, and reduce the overall look and texture of the skin. Achieve an all-over glow plus a younger and healthier appearance.

Yes.

Microdermabrasion and chemical peels are both exfoliative treatments designed to improve skin texture and tone, offering benefits such as tightening the skin, reducing fine lines, evening out skin tone, and minimizing acne scars. While both procedures can be performed in-office by a clinician or at home, they work through different mechanisms: microdermabrasion physically exfoliates by scraping away the topmost layer of skin cells, whereas chemical peels use acid solutions to chemically peel away layers of skin. Chemical peels tend to be more effective for treating acne-prone and sensitive skin, but microdermabrasion is considered safer for darker skin tones. Neither treatment is suitable for all skin types, so careful consideration is needed before choosing one. Both microdermabrasion and light chemical peels can reduce the appearance of large pores--not by shrinking them, which isn't possible, but by clearing excess oil and debris that cause pore dilation, making them appear smaller. Additionally, both treatments help fade dark spots by removing the damaged, pigmented cells in the top layers of skin, allowing healthier new cells to surface. Alternative exfoliating options include laser therapy and at-home treatments, providing a range of choices depending on skin needs and sensitivities.

Safe for all skin types and tones--including darker skin--microdermabrasion works by mechanically buffing the epidermis using a handheld device that sprays exfoliating microcrystals to gently sand away dead skin cells, stimulating new, healthy skin growth. The procedure is generally painless and quick, usually taking around 30 minutes per session. Would you like me to compare these two methods in more detail?
Yes.

Microdermabrasion and chemical peels are both exfoliative treatments designed to improve skin texture and tone, offering benefits such as tightening the skin, reducing fine lines, evening out skin tone, and minimizing acne scars. While both procedures can be performed in-office by a clinician or at home, they work through different mechanisms: microdermabrasion physically exfoliates by scraping away the topmost layer of skin cells, whereas chemical peels use acid solutions to chemically peel away layers of skin. Chemical peels tend to be more effective for treating acne-prone and sensitive skin, but microdermabrasion is considered safer for darker skin tones. Neither treatment is suitable for all skin types, so careful consideration is needed before choosing one. Both microdermabrasion and light chemical peels can reduce the appearance of large pores--not by shrinking them, which isn't possible, but by clearing excess oil and debris that cause pore dilation, making them appear smaller. Additionally, both treatments help fade dark spots by removing the damaged, pigmented cells in the top layers of skin, allowing healthier new cells to surface. Alternative exfoliating options include laser therapy and at-home treatments, providing a range of choices depending on skin needs and sensitivities.
What are the possible side effects?

Side effects of microdermabrasion may include bruising, redness, swelling, tenderness, and in some cases, petechiae--small dark spots that indicate bleeding under the skin. Chemical peels can cause stinging, swelling, and redness, with the duration of these effects ranging from a few days to several weeks, depending on the strength of the peel. Medium and deep chemical peels carry a higher risk and can potentially lead to bacterial infections, so proper aftercare is essential.
Thanks, but what about the rest?

Side effects of laser skin resurfacing can include stinging, itching, peeling, swelling, and redness. After the procedure, your skin might feel like it's sunburned or remain pink for several months. It may also ooze or blister, and initially, there can be some darkening of the skin. Swelling is common for a day or two following the treatment. On the other hand, microneedling side effects may include peeling, bruising, bleeding, and a risk of bacterial infection. Redness after microneedling is normal and usually lasts only a few hours, typically subsiding by the next day. Other common effects include tingling sensations and slight dryness as the skin heals and exfoliates.

context: Hi, I am tired of my skin's appearance, and don't want to wear makeup anymore. What solutions are there except serums?

Since you've been using makeup regularly and already incorporate vitamin C and retinol, are you now looking for something more clinical? Such as in-office treatments that go deeper, such as resurfacing or collagen-boosting procedures?
Yes, I use La Roche-Posay products for my skin and hair, but I am looking for a fast solution. I have heard about CO2 lasers and microneedling. Are they good for me?

Microneedling stimulates the production of collagen and elastin. The collagen hydrates the skin cells, making them plump and full. This naturally shrinks the size of the pores, making your skin look flawless and beautiful. Additionally, microneedling addresses dark spots by breaking up melanin clusters and stimulating skin cell regeneration to produce healthy, unpigmented new tissue. CO2 laser treatment is recommended for anyone who is looking to do the following: Minimize the visibility of wrinkles and fine lines on the face. Reduce the appearance of sun-damaged spots, minimize the size of pores, and reduce the overall look and texture of the skin. Achieve an all-over glow plus a younger and healthier appearance.
How does it work?
Which treatment do you mean?
The latter.

CO2 laser treatment uses a beam of light generated by electricity passing through a gas-filled tube. This light is delivered in short, concentrated pulses that target water in the skin, vaporizing damaged surface cells. It removes the top layer of skin, revealing smoother, fresher skin beneath, while also heating deeper layers to stimulate collagen production, which helps tighten and firm the skin over time. The treatment can be quite intense and may require general anaesthesia, especially for deeper procedures. Recovery time varies: fractional treatments might involve a few days of downtime, while fully ablative ones can require up to two weeks. During healing, the skin is typically swollen, scabbed, and raw, often with itching, discomfort, and minor pinpoint bleeding.
That's too much! How about the other method?

Microneedling requires very little downtime. Most people go back to doing their everyday activities after the treatment. However, you will experience some redness and irritation during the first few days. Therefore, you can apply a light layer of BB cream, tinted moisturizer, or light foundation to cover the redness. You should also apply non-comedogenic sunscreen before going outside. As far as healing times go, you can expect a full recovery after about a week. And after 2 to 3 weeks, you'll start seeing the results of the treatment.
What is the difference between fractional and the other type that you mentioned?

There are two types of CO2 lasers: fully ablative and fractional, with the primary difference being the extent of skin removal, or ablation. Fully ablative CO2 lasers completely remove the superficial skin in the treated area, as their name suggests, while simultaneously heating the deeper dermal layers to stimulate a regenerative healing response that promotes new collagen and elastin production. These treatments tend to be intense, often requiring general anaesthesia, and come with a minimum downtime of about two weeks. However, fully ablative CO2 lasers can paradoxically increase the risk of pigmentation issues and are generally recommended only for individuals with fair or light skin tones.
Are there other techniques?

Those with uneven skin color, dark spots, and pigmentation can benefit significantly from chemical peels, which involve applying specific chemicals to peel off the skin's top layer, allowing fresh, exfoliated skin to regenerate. Recovery time varies depending on the peel's depth: light peels typically require about a week, while medium to deep peels may need over a month for full healing. During recovery, it's essential to avoid abrasive skincare products or techniques to allow the skin to heal properly, and extra care must be taken as chemical peels increase sensitivity to sunlight. Another effective option is microdermabrasion, ideal for individuals looking to reduce signs of photoaging, uneven skin tone and texture, such as hyperpigmentation and melasma, fine lines and wrinkles, enlarged pores, atrophic or indented scars (including acne scars), and stretch marks. Safe for all skin types and tones--including darker skin--microdermabrasion works by mechanically buffing the epidermis using a handheld device that sprays exfoliating microcrystals to gently sand away dead skin cells, stimulating new, healthy skin growth. Chemical peels can cause stinging, swelling, and redness, with the duration of these effects ranging from a few days to several weeks, depending on the strength of the peel. Medium and deep chemical peels carry a higher risk and can potentially lead to bacterial infections, so proper aftercare is essential.
Thanks, but what about the rest?

Side effects of laser skin resurfacing can include stinging, itching, peeling, swelling, and redness. After the procedure, your skin might feel like it's sunburned or remain pink for several months. It may also ooze or blister, and initially, there can be some darkening of the skin. Swelling is common for a day or two following the treatment. On the other hand, microneedling side effects may include peeling, bruising, bleeding, and a risk of bacterial infection. Redness after microneedling is normal and usually lasts only a few hours, typically subsiding by the next day. Other common effects include tingling sensations and slight dryness as the skin heals and exfoliates.
Microneedling sounds good. Can I have my routine after doing it?

Hyaluronic acid is the ultimate post-microneedling ingredient to look for, as it is a naturally occurring substance in the body known for its powerful hydrating and skin-replenishing properties. Applying hyaluronic acid after microneedling enhances its absorption, allowing the serum or treatment to penetrate deeper and work more effectively due to the temporary micro-channels created in the skin. However, it's crucial to avoid applying retinol, makeup, and strong exfoliating acids such as AHAs (alpha hydroxy acids) and BHAs (beta hydroxy acids) immediately after microneedling, as these can cause irritation or even worsen skin sensitivity. It's recommended to wait at least 24 hours post-treatment before using makeup to avoid introducing pore-clogging or irritating ingredients into freshly treated skin. If you use exfoliants containing AHAs like lactic, glycolic, or mandelic acid, apply them either the day before microneedling or wait at least two days after a session--especially when using devices like the Banisher. Additionally, while Vitamin C is a popular antioxidant, it can be sensitizing for some individuals post-microneedling, so it's best to use a gentle, naturally derived, or specifically formulated version to reduce the risk of irritation.

context: Hi, how can I find a good shampoo for my hair?

When choosing a shampoo for an oily scalp, opt for products labelled "volumizing," "strengthening," or "balancing," as these are typically formulated to manage excess oil without adding unnecessary weight. Avoid shampoos that advertise moisturizing, hydrating, or smoothing effects, as well as those designed for curly or frizzy hair--these formulas tend to be too rich and can make oily hair feel heavy or greasy. Look for labels that specifically mention "for oily hair" or highlight oil-controlling and balancing benefits. It's also wise to consider anti-dandruff shampoos, since dandruff is not always a result of dryness; it's often triggered by microscopic fungi that thrive on excess scalp oil, leading to irritation and flaking. For a deeper cleanse, you can occasionally use a clarifying shampoo to remove buildup but limit its use to avoid over-drying or irritating the scalp.

When choosing a shampoo for an oily scalp, opt for products labelled "volumizing," "strengthening," or "balancing," as these are typically formulated to manage excess oil without adding unnecessary weight. How about the formulation of shampoo? Should I look for any specific ingredients?

To help manage an oily scalp, look for shampoos that contain cleansing agents such as sodium lauryl sulphate, ammonium-based compounds, or other effective detergents, as these can help dry out excess oil. Sulfosuccinates are another group of detergents known for their ability to remove buildup without being overly harsh. Salicylic acid is especially effective, as it breaks down oil on the scalp more thoroughly than standard shampoo ingredients. Additionally, natural ingredients like echinacea and sage work to refresh the scalp, slough off dead skin cells, and keep pores and sweat glands clear of obstruction. Tea tree oil is also beneficial, as it actively dissolves and washes away oil and debris, promoting a cleaner and healthier scalp environment.

To manage an oily scalp, try to limit the use of heat styling tools--excessive heat can strip the scalp of its natural oils, triggering it to produce even more oil in response. When conditioning, apply a small amount only to the mid-lengths and ends of your hair--never the scalp--as this can cause buildup, greasiness, and even contribute to hair fall or bacterial growth. Washing your hair about three times per week is usually ideal: frequent cleansing helps control oil, but daily washing may overstimulate sebum production. Keep your pillowcases, bedsheets, and hairbrushes clean, as they can harbour oil and bacteria that contribute to scalp issues. Your diet also plays a key role--limit oily and fried foods and focus instead on healthy fats (like those from nuts or fish) and complex carbs to support balanced sebum levels. If you have an oily scalp and oily hair, several shampoos can help manage oil production while keeping your hair clean and balanced. 1. La Roche-Posay Kerium DS Shampoo is a great choice for oily dandruff. It gently exfoliates the scalp with LHA to remove dead skin cells and prevent flaking, while niacinamide (Vitamin B3) helps soothe itching and irritation. Its targeted delivery system ensures active ingredients reach the scalp where they're most needed to prevent future flare-ups. 2. For a deeper clean once a week, Neutrogena Anti-Residue Shampoo works well to remove product buildup, oil, and dirt from both the scalp and hair. It has a mild, clean scent and leaves your hair feeling refreshed, though it may cause color-treated hair to fade more quickly--so it's best followed by a conditioner. 3. Kerastase Bain Divalent Shampoo is a balanced, gentle formula that cleanses oily roots while nourishing the lengths of your hair. It regulates sebum without stripping the scalp, making hair feel light, soft, and healthy. 4. If you're looking for a more affordable everyday option, L'Oreal Paris Elvive Extraordinary Clay Re-Balancing Shampoo is formulated for oily roots and dry ends. With a blend of three clays, it purifies the scalp and leaves the hair feeling soft, shiny, and bouncy, even though it doesn't lather heavily.

Head & Shoulders Instant Oil Control Anti-Dandruff Shampoo is designed to tackle both oil and flakes from the very first wash. Infused with mango and citrus extracts, it leaves your scalp feeling fresh and your hair up to 100% flake-free. It uses the brand's 3-Action Formula to deeply cleanse the scalp, protect against dandruff, and lightly moisturize the hair without weighing it down--making it a solid option for oily scalps prone to dandruff. On the other hand, OUAI Detox Shampoo is a sulphate-free clarifying shampoo that offers a deeper cleanse. It's made with apple cider vinegar to dissolve excess oil, buildup, and impurities, while keratin helps strengthen and soften the hair. How do Turkish and lavash compare?

Turkish flatbread and lavash are both traditional flatbreads from the Middle East and surrounding regions, but they differ in ingredients, texture, and how they are typically used. Both are healthy, traditional options. Lavash if you want a thinner, more versatile wrap; Turkish flatbread if you're after something heartier and more filling. Lavash has deep cultural roots across Armenia, Azerbaijan, Iran, and Turkey, while Turkish flatbread specifically originates from Turkey and is more like a leavened, fluffy bread compared to other flatbreads. Lavash is traditionally made with unleavened dough, while Turkish flatbread is made with yeast-leavened dough. Lavash is commonly used to wrap or scoop food, especially with kebabs. Turkish flatbread, instead, is often cut open and filled like a sandwich or pita and is best eaten fresh.

Have you ever tried using a timer to dedicate a short burst of focus to a single task?
How exactly does that work?

A great starting point is the Pomodoro Technique: you set a timer for 15-25 minutes of focused work on one single task. If a distracting thought pops up, just jot it down on a notepad to deal with later and gently guide your focus back to the task. When the timer goes off, you take a 5-minute break. This can be especially helpful in a sedentary office job, as you can use that break to stand up and stretch. These breaks also provide a natural opportunity to switch tasks if you feel your focus waning. After four Pomodoros, you take a longer break of 15-30 minutes. This way, you're not just working continuously but also allowing your brain to reset.

My office is pretty quiet, so distractions aren't really a problem. There are so many tasks to do that I constantly feel overwhelmed.

I understand. Feeling overwhelmed by a large workload is definitely something many people with ADHD experience. There are several strategies that can help manage this feeling. One of the most effective approaches is to break down larger tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. This way, you can tackle each part without feeling overwhelmed by the whole task. Would you like to explore some specific techniques for breaking down tasks, or perhaps discuss how to prioritize them effectively?
Won't that just create even more tasks to do?

That is a valid concern. However, the idea isn't to create more work - it's about dividing one big overwhelming task into smaller, concrete steps. The key to feeling less overwhelmed is to make each step as specific as possible. For example, instead of "write report," you could break it down into "collect data", "create a draft", "write introduction", etc. This way, each step feels more achievable. Would you like me to help you come up with a specific example based on your current tasks at work?

Hm, not sure about that. My main problem is that if I have more than one task at hand, I just can't properly focus on any of them. I end up jumping from one task to another without finishing anything.

Ah, that sounds like you're experiencing "ADHD paralysis", where your brain gets stuck between tasks and can't initiate any of them. It's less about the number of tasks and more about the executive function challenge of choosing one and sticking with it. This is a frustrating experience, but there are strategies that can help you manage it. One effective approach is to work with your ADHD rather than against it. Since focusing on one task for a long time can be difficult, try choosing two tasks you need to get done and switching between them throughout the day. This can boost your productivity because when your attention starts to wane on one task, you can shift to the other. Have you ever tried using a timer to dedicate a short burst of focus to a single task?
How exactly does that work?

A great starting point is the Pomodoro Technique: you set a timer for 15-25 minutes of focused work on one single task. If a distracting thought pops up, just jot it down on a notepad to deal with later and gently guide your focus back to the task. When the timer goes off, you take a 5-minute break. This can be especially helpful in a sedentary office job, as you can use that break to stand up and stretch. These breaks also provide a natural opportunity to switch tasks if you feel your focus waning. After four Pomodoros, you take a longer break of 15-30 minutes. This way, you're not just working continuously but also allowing your brain to reset.
It's a bit too strict. Sometimes I don't want to interrupt my hyperfocus with a timer. Any other suggestions?

Absolutely. Finding your "flow" or hyperfocus is a superpower, and you don't want to interrupt it unnecessarily. In that case, you can try experimenting and finding what works for you, rather than rigidly adhering to someone else's system. You can try creating a daily bulleted list and tackling tasks in a flexible order - without worrying about the "how and when" as long as they get done. Another alternative approach that might work is the "Flowtime" technique. It's like a flexible version of the Pomodoro method. You pick a task, start a timer, and work for as long as you feel focused. When you feel your attention waning, you stop the timer, note how long you worked, and take a break for as long as you need. It's about honoring your natural rhythms rather than fighting against them.
Do you have any tips on how to deal with distractions that might come up during my hyperfocus? e.g. if I get an email or have a scheduled meeting?

Sure! For emails, consider setting specific times to check and respond to them, rather than letting them interrupt your deep work periods. As for scheduled meetings, those are often fixed, so you can plan your focused work sessions around them. Would you be interested in exploring strategies for batching tasks like email, or perhaps discuss how to prepare for meetings so they don't completely throw off your momentum?
Meetings.

With meetings, a good strategy is to prepare beforehand. Review the agenda, if there is one, and write down any questions or points you want to raise. This helps you stay engaged and less likely to drift off.
No, I mean the meetings as a distraction.

Ah, I see. You're concerned that the interruption of a meeting itself breaks your concentration and makes it hard to get back into your focused work. That's a very common experience for people with ADHD. It's not just about what happens during the meeting, but the transition in and out. Is that what you're referring to? If so, we can discuss strategies to manage those transitions better, like creating a routine before and after meetings to help you reset your focus. Would that be helpful for you?

Got it! Since you can draw well, you're already on the right track. In addition to your tattoo machine and fake skin, you'll need some basic supplies, including tattoo needles, ink, and a power supply for your machine. It's also important to have proper hygiene supplies like gloves, disinfectant, and a clean workspace to ensure safety and cleanliness while tattooing. Yes please.

Understanding tattoo needle types is crucial for achieving different effects in your artwork, even on fake skin. It's a bit like choosing the right brush for a painting! Tattoo needles are generally categorized by their configuration (grouping). There are Round Liners (RL), Round Shaders (RS), Stacked Magnum (M1), Round Magnum and Flat Needles. Round Liners are primarily used for outlining the design. They come in various sizes, affecting the thickness of the line. These include 3RL, 5RL, 7RL, and even larger groupings, with the number indicating how many needles are in the grouping. Round Shaders are designed for shading or colouring between the lines of the RL outline. Similar to RL, they come in different sizes, like 5RS or 7RS. Stacked Magnum are best suited for blending and shading smaller areas while Round Magnum are for colouring in larger areas without overworking the skin. Finally, Flat Needles are used for shapes and intricate shading, like geometric designs or bold lines. As a hobbyist, starting with a few common types like a 3RL or 5RL for lines, and a 7RS or 9M1 for shading, would give you a good range to experiment with on your fake skin. Focus on understanding how each type feels and how it deposits ink, and you'll quickly develop a feel for what works best for different design elements.

What is reach?

REACH compliance refers to the European Union's regulation on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals. It ensures that chemicals used in products, including tattoo inks and needles, are safe for human health and the environment. When a product is REACH compliant, it means that it has been tested and meets the safety standards set by the EU. This is particularly important in tattooing, as the inks and materials used can have direct contact with the skin. Using REACH compliant products helps ensure that you are using safe and regulated materials, which is especially crucial when you eventually move from practicing on fake skin to real skin.

What is reach?

REACH compliance refers to the European Union's regulation on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals. Understanding tattoo needle types is crucial for achieving different effects in your artwork, even on fake skin. It's a bit like choosing the right brush for a painting! Tattoo needles are generally categorized by their configuration (grouping). There are Round Liners (RL), Round Shaders (RS), Stacked Magnum (M1), Round Magnum and Flat Needles. Round Liners are primarily used for outlining the design. They come in various sizes, affecting the thickness of the line. These include 3RL, 5RL, 7RL, and even larger groupings, with the number indicating how many needles are in the grouping. Round Shaders are designed for shading or colouring between the lines of the RL outline. Similar to RL, they come in different sizes, like 5RS or 7RS. Stacked Magnum are best suited for blending and shading smaller areas while Round Magnum are for colouring in larger areas without overworking the skin. Finally, Flat Needles are used for shapes and intricate shading, like geometric designs or bold lines. As a hobbyist, starting with a few common types like a 3RL or 5RL for lines, and a 7RS or 9M1 for shading, would give you a good range to experiment with on your fake skin. context: Hi! I bought a second-hand bike last week. I want to inspect and upgrade a few parts, what do you suggest I check first?

When checking a second-hand bike, start by making sure the wheels aren't bent and that the seat and rear frame are properly aligned with the rest of the bike. You should also check that the front part, especially the headlight, is pointing straight. If anything looks misaligned, like the steering or rear wheel being off by a centimeter or so, it's best to get it repaired or replaced safely. Used bikes can also have issues with the swingarm, so it's good to be cautious there too. If you're unsure, a mechanic can do a full check-up and give you a written report (usually around $250) confirming everything is in good shape. That might be a good option for you, especially since you mentioned you're not very handy with DIY. By the way, what kind of bike is it, mountain, road, or city? And how much did you pay for it?

Since you ride a mountain bike and comfort is a top priority, especially with your history of back pain, there are several features beyond foam or gel that are worth considering when choosing a saddle. First, the shape of the saddle really matters. Mountain biking involves a lot of movement and shifting positions, especially on rough or hilly terrain. A narrower saddle helps with maneuverability, while a wider rear provides better support for your sit bones. You'll want something that balances both. Also, durability and weather resistance are important, especially since you ride in the rain and on forest paths. Look for a weatherproof cover that won't get slick or degrade quickly in wet conditions. Saddle height and positioning also play a role in comfort. If you're riding cross-country, a slightly higher saddle can help with pedaling efficiency. For more technical trails or downhill rides, a lower saddle improves control. You might even want to consider a dropper post if you're doing both. Finally, padding isn't everything, comfort also depends on how well the saddle fits your body and riding style. Many mountain bike saddles are designed to support the sit bones while staying streamlined enough for effective pedaling. Would you like some help narrowing it down to a few specific models?

That sounds good, what are the key things to look for?

A few things really matter when choosing flat pedals. First, go for a robust body material, aluminum and magnesium offer better strength-to-weight ratios than plastic. Second, look for replaceable metal pins; they provide superior grip, and you can swap them out if they wear down. You'll also want sealed bearings or bushings, which protect against dirt and moisture, especially if you ride through wet forests or muddy trails. Lastly, check the platform size, a wider platform gives more stability, especially with trail or downhill shoes. If you can, try a model with slightly concave shape, it helps lock your foot in place naturally.

context: Hi, my bike chain keeps going out, what is the issue?
There is probably an issue with your chain, or gears, would you like a DIY guide, or do you prefer to go to a bike shop for them to fix it?

There are lots of reasons why your chain could be jumping off, or even going out. First, it can be just common wear, if you had your bike for long time, it is normal you need to change the chains regularly. It is especially true if you bike in rainy weather or mud. Another reason could also be the derailleur. When you change speed, the derailleur shifts the chain, if it is not well adjusted it can go too far in one direction, or even still shift it although there is no gear to catch it. This can be adjusted easily, just check limit screws labelled "H" and "L" for "High" and "Low" limits.

context: Hi, my bike chain keeps going out, what is the issue?

I rather fix it myself, I have some tools, and some time.

There are lots of reasons why your chain could be jumping off, or even going out. First, it can be just common wear, if you had your bike for long time, it is normal you need to change the chains regularly. It is especially true if you bike in rainy weather or mud. Another reason could also be the derailleur. When you change speed, the derailleur shifts the chain, if it is not well adjusted it can go too far in one direction, or even still shift it although there is no gear to catch it. This can be adjusted easily, just check limit screws labelled "H" and "L" for "High" and "Low" limits.

Ok. here is another more hands-on method, also very reliable, called the big-big method. You could use motor oil, but it is not the ideal case because bike and car oils have different properties. If you apply your grease correctly, you could easily bike for 200 miles without any problem, while with poor quality oil, you might have to do extra maintenance.
